title: (x) Chunky, filled-in, stencil - Kada {Simon H}
content:
Since this typeface has been showing up everywhere the answer may be simple...

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081203173721im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/chunky_4615.jpg)

 [‹ (x) D.L. Evans Bank logo - ITC Benguiat {Jan E}](http://web.archive.org/web/20081203173721/http:/www.typophile.com/node/39310 "Go to previous forum topic") [(x) Typewriter font in "Vitamin D - new perspectives in drawing" - Everson Mono {Florian} ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081203173721/http:/www.typophile.com/node/39267 "Go to next forum topic")
author: armin

comments.content: Sorry, I don’t know about this faux-stencil variation. But the archetype of the fat rounded wurst face, to me, is [Frankfurter](http://web.archive.org/web/20081203173721/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/letraset/frankfurter/familytree.html).
Kada from Lineto.com, Frankfurter’s rebellious offspring.
Thanks guys. Also, by “cunky” I meant “chunky”. But I would love to see what a cunky typeface looks like.

There are a couple versions of this style. One is Lineto’s Kada, the other is a [custom proprietary font](http://web.archive.org/web/20081203173721/http:/wearebuild.com/projects/d-and-ad) by Michael C. Place (Build) which is based on an old film or transfer face.

If you want an alternative without stencils, go for the [Gusto](http://web.archive.org/web/20081203173721/http:/www.flickr.com/photos/stewf/376112212/).
